sn47.6:4.1: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a hawk suddenly swooped down and grabbed a quail.
sn47.6:4.2: And as the quail was being carried off he wailed:
sn47.6:4.3: ‘I’m so unlucky, so unfortunate, to have roamed out of my territory into the domain of others.
sn47.6:4.4: If today I’d roamed within my own territory, the domain of my fathers, this hawk wouldn’t have been able to beat me by fighting.’
sn47.6:4.6: ‘So, quail, what is your own territory, the domain of your fathers?’
sn47.6:4.8: ‘It’s a ploughed field covered with clods of earth.’
sn47.6:4.9: Because of her own strength, the hawk was not daunted or intimidated. She released the quail, saying:
sn47.6:4.10: ‘Go now, quail. But even there you won’t escape me!’
sn47.6:5.1: Then the quail went to a ploughed field covered with clods of earth. He climbed up a big clod, and standing there, he said to the hawk:
sn47.6:5.2: ‘Come get me, hawk! Come get me, hawk!’
sn47.6:5.3: Because of her own strength, the hawk was not daunted or intimidated. She folded her wings and suddenly swooped down on the quail.
sn47.6:5.4: When the quail knew that the hawk was nearly there, he slipped under that clod.
sn47.6:5.5: And the hawk crashed chest-first right there.
sn47.6:5.6: That’s what happens when you roam out of your territory into the domain of others.
sn47.6:6.1: So, mendicants, don’t roam out of your own territory into the domain of others.
sn47.6:6.2: If you roam out of your own territory into the domain of others, Māra will find a vulnerability and get hold of you.
sn47.6:6.3: And what is not a mendicant’s own territory but the domain of others?
sn47.6:6.5: It’s the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
sn47.6:6.7: Sights cognizable by the eye that are likeable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. Sounds cognizable by the ear …
sn47.6:6.10: Touches cognizable by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
sn47.6:6.11: This is not a mendicant’s own territory but the domain of others.
sn47.6:7.1: You should roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers.
sn47.6:7.2: If you roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers, Māra won’t find a vulnerability or get hold of you.
sn47.6:7.3: And what is a mendicant’s own territory, the domain of the fathers?
sn47.6:7.5: It’s the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn47.6:7.7: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.6:7.8: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.6:7.10: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.6:7.11: This is a mendicant’s own territory, the domain of the fathers.”
